overview: This document (2403.14662v1 [cs.CY]) focuses on AI policy development in Africa, arguing that existing global readiness assessments fail to fully capture African states' progress and identifying crucial nuances often overlooked. It advocates for a tailored approach to global assessments, emphasizing the importance of addressing local governance challenges and resource availability that vary geographically.
challenges: Weak or insufficient data protection regimes (Mauritius)
Complications in achieving robust oversight frameworks to support sustained sector growth (Kenya, Egypt)
Limited governance and economic resources to devote to technological and workforce development (Angola)
Existing gaps in source data on which assessments are based ignore significant policy and economic achievements of African states
solutions: Tailored approach to global assessments, emphasizing the importance of addressing local governance challenges and resource availability.
Regional and Continental Cooperation: Sharing best practices, improving global competitiveness.
Public Engagement and Development of Human Capital: Implementing clear opportunities for public input and incorporating workforce development and technical skill-building provisions.
Harnessing local AI talent by recruiting experts for taskforces to guide governmental efforts on AI regulation (Angola).
Strategic investments in building AI institutes to facilitate the scaling of local AI research (Angola).
Integrating STEM training into primary and secondary school curricula and investing in post-secondary training and upskilling initiatives (Angola).
required_capabilities: National policies or strategies for creating baseline technological engagement and deployment
Capacity for data collection and maintenance
Electrical and data infrastructure to enhance research capabilities
